standard-rules.title: Chess
standard-rules.quote: “The game of chess is a lake in which a mosquito can bathe and an elephant can drown.” – Indian Proverb

steps.text:
Chess is a modern, western variation of a type of board game that has been played for thousands of years. 
 Games of this family have a coordinate system as well as a set of movable figures, one of which is deemed important to the game's result.
This tutorial will not cover the basics of chess rules. If you are unfamiliar with chess, the free online platform lichess.org has a great comprehensive tutorial.
steps.note: The starting position for chess. Push the pawn in front of the king two squares forward to complete this exercise.

fairy-chess.title: Fairy Chess
fairy-chess.quote: “We do these things for ourselves alone.” – Thomas Dawson, fairy chess composer

steps.text:
“Fairy Chess“ is a general term for a chess variant that includes nonstandard piece types. 
 Below is a variant imagined by José Raúl Capablanca, a world chess champion. Note the 10x8 board and the addition of two new piece types.

Variants such as Capablanca's chess were intended for full games, but it was also popular in some historical chess communities to invent new pieces for the sake of compositions (puzzles). Below is a 1911 puzzle by Thomas Dawson, a prolific composer of fairy chess problems. It involves a piece which combines the movement of a rook and a knight.
steps.note: White to move, mate in 2. Hint: you only need to move the special piece.

token-chess.title: Token Chess
token-chess.quote: “We do these things for ourselves alone.” – Thomas R. Dawson, composer of over 5,000 fairy chess problems.

steps.text: When capturing, pawns must move one square diagonally.
steps.note: White to move and mate and two. Hint: you only need to move the special piece.

Champion.title: Champion
Champion.quote: “I can't be defeated. I beat all men. Someday, I will beat a real champion. If he dies, he dies.” – Ivan Drago

steps.text:
The Champion combines the movement of the Rook and Knight pieces. It a classic addition in chess variants. 
 José Raúl Capablanca called it the “Chancellor,“ a popular name for the piece, but Token Chess refers to it by the name given by its first introduction to western chess by Italian priest Pietro Carrera.
steps.note: Capture the rook, then capture the bishop.

steps.text: You can castle with the Champion, just as you would a rook!
steps.note: Castle with the Champion.

Princess.title: Princess
Princess.quote: “Your princess is quite a winning creature. Her appeal is undeniable.” – The Princess Bride

steps.text: The Princess combines the movement of the Rook and Knight pieces. Like the Champion, it is a piece with a long history in chess variants. It is a tricky piece that is quite irritating to play against-- in an open board, the Princess is difficult to escape.
steps.note: Retreat the Princess to pin the enemy Rook.

Amazon.title: Amazon
Amazon.quote: “It is much safer to be feared than loved...” – Machiavelli

steps.text: Combining the power of the Queen with that of a Knight, the Amazon is extremely powerful. Unlike any piece in standard chess, it can perform a checkmate without any additional help.
steps.note: Checkmate the enemy King in one move.

Commoner.title: Commoner
Commoner.quote: “That a peasant may become king does not render the kingdom democratic.” – Woodrow Wilson

steps.text:
The Commoner is just like a King, but as it was not born into royalty, it cannot be checkmated. 
 While a weak attacker, the Commoner is strong in endgames. For example, despite having the same token cost as a Bishop or Knight, the Commoner can perform checkmate with the help of the King.
steps.note: Checkmate the enemy King in three moves.

steps.text: There's more! If sufficiently close to your King, this little endgame magician can effortlessly ward off a Queen, drawing a game down 5 points of material.
steps.note: Use the Commoner to block the checks.

Painter.title: Royal Painter
Painter.quote: “I dream my paintings, and then I paint my dreams.” – van Gogh

steps.text: While similar to a pawn, the Royal Painter has no stomach for violence. They are not a fighter but a dreamer and an artist. Rather than capture, the Painter paints enemy pieces to its own color.
steps.note: Push the painter, then paint the enemy Rook.

steps.text: While similar to a pawn, the Royal Painter has no stomach for violence. They are not a fighter but a dreamer and an artist. Rather than capture, the Painter paints enemy pieces to its own color.
steps.note: Push the painter, then paint en passant (en paintssant).

steps.text: The Snare is a piece that restricts the movement of enemy pieces within a certain range. The Snare can only move forward, and cannot capture.
steps.note: Push the Snare forward, then click black's pieces to see which ones can move.

steps.text: The Snare can be a good way to win material. It is generally a good idea to ensnare a target that can easily be attacked, such as with a pawn.
steps.note: Ensnare the enemy Queen, then attack it with a pawn.

steps.text: Note that since the Snare cannot capture, it cannot give check. However, a King may be ensnared. In this case, the opposing side may deliver mate by simply giving a check.
steps.note: Ensnare the King, then deliver checkmate.

Wizard.title: Wizard
Wizard.quote: “A wizard is never late. Nor is he early. He arrives precisely when he means to.” – Gandalf

steps.text: The Wizard moves up to two squares orthogonally, disregarding occupancy of squares in between.
steps.note: Jump over the pawn, then capture the bishop.

steps.text: The true power of the Wizard lies in its ability to swap places with a friendly piece within its movement range. This ability disregards pins, unlike standard chess rules which disallow moving “through“ check.
steps.note: Escape the pin.

steps.text: The Wizard creates value by relocating poorly positioned pieces with low mobility. For example, a Wizard may create a passed pawn from an otherwise deadlocked structure.
steps.note: Use the wizard to create a passed pawn, then push the pawn.

steps.text: The Wizard may be used to escape the King from dangerous places, including positions which would otherwise be checkmate!
steps.note: Escape the checkmate attempt.

steps.text: While not a strong attacker, the Wizard is sufficient to deliver checkmate in an endgame.
steps.note: Use the Wizard to checkmate in three moves.

Archer.title: Archer
Archer.quote: “Swift as the wind, silent as the forest.” – Sun Tzu

steps.text: The Archer is a slow piece, moving one square diagonally at a time. This makes it a color-bound piece, like the Bishop.
steps.note: Capture the pawns.

steps.text: The Archer has the unique ability to capture without moving, given that the captured piece is 2 to 3 diagonal squares away.
steps.note: Capture the pieces in the following order: Knight, Rook, Pawn

token-system.title: The Token System
token-system.quote: “The pawn is the soul of chess.” – Philidor

steps.text: Tokens give you budgeted points to spend on pieces. Use the Army Builder to create armies using the token budget.
In the Army Builder you can save and export armies as JSON so the Board Editor can place them.
